StringWithMarkup.String: Dibenz(a,h)anthracene was detected in 32 of 62 soil samples collected from Boston, MA, Springfield, Ma, and Providence, RI in July 1992 at concentrations ranging from 0.02 to 2.90 mg/kg(1). Dibenz(a,h)anthracene was detected in coal-tar contaminated soil samples from a manufactured gas plant in New York at a concentration of 26 ug/g(2). A composite soil sample collected from areas around a plastics recycling facility fire in Hamilton, Ontario, Canada contained a dibenz(a,h)anthracene concentration of 0.50 ug/g(3). Dibenz(a,h)anthracene was detected in soil samples taken from an existing petroleum refinery land treatment site in Washington state at concentrations of 310 and 47 mg/kg at depths of 0 to 6 and 12 to 24 inches, respectively4). Lava and humus samples from Iceland contained 0 to 2.3 ug/kg dibenz(a,h)anthracene. A soil sample from an airfield contained 351 ug/kg dibenz(a,h)anthracene(5). Soil samples collected in the vicinity of a large incinerator plant in Italy, contained dibenz(a,h)anthracene at concentrations ranging from 2 to 335 ng/g(6). 16 of 18 soil samples from sites of the Swiss Soil Monitoring Network were found to contain dibenz(a,h)anthracene at concentrations ranging from 2 to 10 ug/kg dry weight, with a mean concentration of 3.6 ug/kg dry weight(7). Soil samples taken from a former wood impregnation plant and a former tar oil refinery (location not specified) contained dibenz(a,h)anthracene at concentrations of 1.1 and 26.2 mg/kg soil, respectively(8). Agricultural soil, sampled in northern Greece, contained 0-1.9 ug/kg dry weight of dibenz(a,h)anthracene(9). Dibenz(a,h)anthracene was detected in 44 surface soil samples from 49 study sites in Wales at concentrations ranging from 0.8 to 666 ug/kg dry weight (mean concentration 65 ug/kg dry weight); the highest concentration occurring in a soil sample from an industrialized area of the Upper Taff valley (coal-mining valley), the lowest concentration occurring in a soil sample from a rural pasture(10). Soil samples collected from 188 sampling sites in the Tianjin area, China (farmland, mountainous areas, city, oil field) contained a mean dibenz(a,h)anthracene level of 0.40 ug/g(11).

StringWithMarkup.String: URBAN/SUBURBAN: Air samples collected at Anthony (St. Denis) in the Paris area contained dibenz(a,h)anthracene at concentration of, ng/cu m: Aug 1979, 0.012(0.029); Oct 1979, 0.50(0.69); Jan 1980, 0.98(2.8)(1). Aerosols collected from 12 sites in 4 urbanized areas in the western US contained dibenz(a,h)anthracene at concentrations ranging from 2 to 120 pg/cu m(2). Air samples from Osaka, Japan contained dibenz(a,h)anthracene at the following concentrations, ng/cu m: Nov 1981, 1.15; Jan 1982, 1.19; Mar, 0.46; Aug, 1.06; avg 0.97(3). Dibenz(a,h)anthracene was detected in air dust and tunnel dust samples from 12 German cities at concentrations ranging from 3.2 to 32 ng/cu m and 4 to 39 ppb, respectively(4). Air samples collected from Rorvik, Sweden between Feb to Mar, 1977, contained dibenz(a,h)anthracene at concentrations ranging from not detected to 0.84 ng/cu m(5). The regional dibenz(a,h)anthracene average air concentration for the middle of the Ruhr area, Germany was 2.6, 2.4, and 2.3 ng/cu m in 1991, 1992, and 1993, respectively(6). The mean particle bound ambient air dibenz(a,h)anthracene concentration at seven urban and one rural site near Augsbrug, Germany was 0.16 ng/cu m in 1992(7). The average dibenz(a,h)anthracene ambient air concentration along Exhibition Road, UK between Jan 1991 and July 1992 was 0.13 ng/cu m(8). Airborne particulate samples collected from the Upper Silesia region of Poland, in the winter of 1988-89 and the summer of 1989, were found to contain dibenz(a,h)anthracene (number of times detected, concentration range in ng/cu m): winter (4, 2.1 to 14.9) and summer (9, 1.0 to 23.6)(9). Ambient air samples collected throughout Singapore from July to Dec 1983 contained dibenz(a,h)anthracene at concentrations ranging from 3.4 to 8.4 ug/1000 cu m(10). The yearly mean particulate-phase dibenz(a,h)anthracene concentrations obtained at urban sites in Lahore, Pakistan and Birmingham, UK were 3.85 and 0.43 ng/cu m, respectively(11). In Ionia and Sindos, Greece atmospheric particulate concentrations ranged from 0.12-15 ng/cu m and 0.14-35 ng/cu m respectively in 1993-1994(12). Winter and summer air monitoring at two sites in Hong Kong between 1998-2005 detected dibenz(a,h)anthracene at average winter and summer concentrations of 0.78-1.08 and 0.14-0.24 ng/cu m respectively(13). Median dibenz(a,h)anthracene concentrations of 0.26 and 0.03 ng/cu m were detected, respectively, in particulate-phase and gas-phase air samples collected in Singapore in June 2007 and may 2008(14). Air monitoring conducted between 2007-2008 at urban sites in Harbin, China detected average dibenz(a,h)anthracene concentrations of 0.4-2.1 ng/cu m(15).

Reference: (1) Gale RW et al; Environ Sci Technol 43: 3054-3060 (2009)
(2) Gevao B et al; Arch Environ Contam Toxicol 53: 503-512 (2007)

StringWithMarkup.String: RURAL/REMOTE: Aerosols collected over Norway in the winter of 1977, contained dibenz(a,h)anthracene at concentrations ranging from not detected to 0.52 ng/cu m; when the origin of air was northern Norway the low concentration was observed and high concentrations were observed when the origin of air was England and France(1). StringWithMarkup.String: Dibenz(a,h)anthracene was detected in: spinach, 0.3 ppb; tomatoes, 0.04 ppb; cereals, 0.1 to 0.6 ppb; and charcoal-broiled steaks, 0.2 ppb(1). StringWithMarkup.String: Dibenz(a,h)anthracene was detected in (mean concentration, ug/kg): margarine (0.3), mussels (2.2), spinach (0.05), and kale (0.4), The Netherlands (1). The following South Indian foods were found to contain dibenz(a,h)anthracene (concentration, ug/g): cumin seeds (0.509); chappatti, wheat flour item (3.695); calamus (0.129); oil-fried, salted and sun-dried chiles (27.480); oil-fried, salted and sun-dried cluster beans (9.540); decoction made from pyrolysed cumin seeds + mint leaves + cardamom (31.150); aniseeds (0.302); and sundakkai (0.621)(2). StringWithMarkup.String: Dibenz(a,h)anthracene was detected in carrot peels and cores grown in sewage sludge-amended soils(1). Dibenz(a,h)anthracene was detected in the leaves of 13 (out of 15) evergreen trees, Laurus nobilis, collected in the Valley of Florence, Italy in Feb 1991 at concentrations ranging from 0.3 to 7.9 ug/kg dry weight(3). Pooled grass samples from the Park Grass grassland in Rothamsted, UK (42 km north of Central London) taken between the years 1860 to 1986 contained dibenz(a,h)anthracene at the following concentrations, ug/kg (pooled years): 1 (1860 to 1862); 6 (1879 to 1881); 6 (1920 to 1923); 11 (1940 to 41); 4 (1957 to 1958); and 1 (1985 to 1986)(4). Dibenz(a,h)anthracene was detected at levels of <5 to 16 ng/g in moss (Hylocomium splendens, Pleurozium schreberi) collected in the southern mountains of Poland in July 2005(5).

StringWithMarkup.String: 100% of the softshell clams (Mya arenaria) sampled (2 sites, 6 sampling days) in Coos Bay, OR in 1978-79 contained dibenz(a,h)anthracene at concentrations ranging from 1.5 to 6.7 ppb, average concentrations of 4.7 and 6.9 ppb(1). 100% of mussels (Mytilus edulis) taken from Yaquina Bay, OR in 1979-80,(2 sites, 16 and 12 sampling days) contained dibenz(a,h)anthracene at concentrations ranging from 0.5 to 3.6 ppb and 4.9 to 12.6 ppb, respectively, average concentrations of 2.1 and 9.6 ppb, respectively(2). Dibenz(a,h)anthracene was detected the invasive asian clam (Potamocorbula amurensis) from Suisan Bay estuary, San Francisco Bay, CA at a concentration of 15 ng/g dry weight(4).  Dibenz(a,h)anthracene was detected in the stomach contents of white croaker collected from the San Pedro Bay, CA during Dec 1984 at concentrations ranging from 64 (Reservation Point) to 480 (Cerritos Channel) ng/g dry weight; white croaker (Genyonemus lineatus) samples from White Point and Hyperion were found to contain dibenz(a,h)anthracene at concentrations <33 and <6 ng/g dry weight, respectively(5).

StringWithMarkup.String: Dibenz(a,h)anthracene has been identified in: main stream cigarette smoke, 0.1 to 0.15 mg/kg cigarette smoke condensate; main stream smoke of marijuana cigarettes; gasoline engine exhaust tar, 2.5 mg/kg tar; coal-heating exhaust; used engine oil, 14.32 mg/kg; coal-tar(1). Dibenz(a,h)anthracene has been detected in soot and coal-tar at concentrations ranging from 64 to 705 mg/1000 cu m soot and 230 to 300 mg/kg, respectively(2). The concentration of dibenz(a,h)anthracene in treated wood poles (eg, telephone poles) and railway ties (in one composite sample of 25 subsamples) was 7 and 16 mg/kg dry weight, respectively(5). Dibenz(a,h)anthracene has been detected in: compost, 2,350 ug/kg dry weight; horse manure 18 ug/kg dry weight; wood preservative sludge, 70 mg/L of raw sludge; in gasoline (high octane number), 0.167 mg/L; in coal tar, 2,130 mg/kg of sample; cigarette smoke, 0.4 ug/100 cigarettes; exhaust condensate of gasoline engine, 96 ug/g; airborne coal tar emissions, 0.41 mg/g of sample or 14 ug/cu m of air sampled; in coke oven airborne emissions, 84 to 124 ug/g of sample(6). Dibenz(a,h)anthracene was detected in pig and cattle liquid manure samples, collected from pits on farms at Swiss Soil Monitoring Network sites, at mean concentrations of 2.0 and 2.8 ug/kg dry weight, respectively(7). Dibenz(a,h)anthracene was found in street dust collected from Niteroi City, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil(8). StringWithMarkup.String: OBJECTIVES: Relative importance of multiple indoor and outdoor venues on personal exposure concentrations to pro-carcinogenic polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (c-PAHs) remains poorly understood. This is particularly challenging because many c-PAHs share sources and occur as a complex mixture. Accurate and precise apportionment of personal exposure according to exposure venues could aid in the understanding of human health effects due to a given source. Here, we partitioned indoor and personal exposure concentrations to seven c-PAHs and pyrene according to the indoor- and outdoor-origins. METHODS: A simultaneous, integrated monitoring of personal, indoor and outdoor concentrations of nine PAHs was conducted in 75 homes for a consecutive 48-hour period across a two-year period in Krakow, Poland. Due to few known indoor sources for chrysene, we used this PAH species as a tracer for infiltration of outdoor PAHs. Personal and indoor concentrations of seven c-PAHs and pyrene were apportioned to home indoor, non-home indoor and outdoor origins. RESULTS: Using Chrysene-in/Chrysene-out as proxy for an infiltration factor, Finf, infiltrated PAHs of outdoor origin are overall higher in concentration than those emitted from the indoor origin. Average contribution by the outdoor sources on B[a]A, B[b]F, and B[k]F were 92%, 79%, and 78% across all seasons, respectively. In contrast, in homes where a household member smoked, average contributions by the outdoor sources on B[ghi]P, B[a]P, D[ah]A, and IP were lower (i.e., 67%, 65%, 67%, and 66%, respectively). Season-averaged contributions by the outdoor sources on personal exposure to B[a]A, B[b]F, and B[k]F were 92%, 74%, and 77%, respectively. On the other hand, season-averaged home indoor source contributions on personal exposure to B[a]A, B[b]F, and B[k]F were estimated at 6%, 15%, and 19%, respectively. Similar contributions by season-averaged home indoor sources on personal exposure were estimated at 28% for B[ghi]P, 31% for B[a]P, 25% for D[ah]A, and 28% for IP. CONCLUSION: Of the seven c-PAHs, B[a]A, B[b]F, and B[k]F are enriched in indoor and personal exposure concentrations from the outdoor coal-combustion. B[ghi]P, B[a]P, D[a,h]A, and IP, PAHs with some of the highest carcinogenic and mutagenic potencies, are considerably enriched by cigarette smoke in addition to the outdoor sources.

Section.Description: In the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) classification, chemicals are categorized into four groups: Group 1 (carcinogenic to humans), Group 2A (probably carcinogenic to humans), Group 2B (possibly carcinogenic to humans), and Group 3 (not classifiable as to its carcinogenicity to humans).

EPA Chemicals under the Toxic Substances Control Act (TSCA) collection contains information on chemicals and their regulation under TSCA. The chemical classification tree is created based on the TSCA substance regulatory flag, UVCB, and commercial activity status.

Substance Registry Services (SRS) is the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) central system for information about substances that are tracked or regulated by EPA or other sources. It is a resource for basic information about chemicals, biological organisms, and other substances of interest to EPA and its state and tribal partners. SRS makes it possible to identify which EPA data systems, environmental statutes, or other sources have information about a substance and which synonym is used by that system or statute.

The World Intellectual Property Organisation (WIPO) is a specialized United Nations (UN) agency headquartered in Geneva (Switzerland). Our mission is to lead the development of a balanced and effective international Intellectual Property (IP) system that enables innovation and creativity for the benefit of all. We help governments, businesses and society realize the benefits of Intellectual Property and are notably a world reference source for IP information.
